I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Regional cooperation in transport is essential to link the landlocked countries of Central 
Asia closely with neighboring countries and facilitate efficient cross-border movements of freight 
and passengers so as to achieve rapid and sustainable economic development. The Central 
Asia Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) Program, initiated by the Asian Development 
bank (ADB) in 1997, aims to strengthen economic linkages among Afghanistan, Azerbaijan, 
People’s Republic of China (PRC: Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region), Kazakhstan, Kyrgyz 
Republic, Mongolia, Tajikistan, and Uzbekistan. Transport is one of the priority areas under 
CAREC. Important progress has been made on transport cooperation among CAREC countries. 
The Transport Sector Coordinating Committee (TSCC) was established in June 2004, a regional 
transport sector road map for 2005–2010 was developed in March 2005, and investments were 
made to improve regional transport networks. 
 
2.  In accordance with ongoing efforts to support transport cooperation among CAREC 
countries, ADB includes this regional technical assistance (TA)1 in the 2005 program of its 
Central  Asia  Regional  Cooperation  Strategy  and  Program  Update  (2006–2008).2 The  TA 
proposal was presented at the fourth TSCC Meeting in Bishkek, Kyrgyz Republic on 12–13 
October 2005. Concurrence was reached with the governments of CAREC countries on the 
impact, outcome, outputs, cost, financing and implementation arrangements, and consultants’ 
terms of reference for the TA. The TA design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Central Asia is a historical land bridge between East Asia and Europe, as well as 
between South Asia/Persian Gulf and Russia. It also has a potential to become important transit 
routes between Asia and Europe. However, CAREC countries face daunting challenges in 
promoting  regional  and  international  transit  transport:  regional  transport  networks  are 
inadequate, a large proportion of regional transport infrastructure and facilities are in poor 
condition due to insufficient funding for maintenance, and nonphysical barriers are becoming 
major impediments to cross-border and transit traffic. These challenges need to be addressed 
jointly by CAREC countries through close cooperation. 
 
4.  In response to the challenges, CAREC countries established the TSCC in June 2004 to 
coordinate issues and activities relating to regional transport cooperation. TSCC has adopted a 
pragmatic, phased, and results-based approach. It meets twice a year to review cooperation 
progress and provide guidance on future work as necessary. Four TSCC meetings3 have been 
held. The Regional Transport Sector Road Map (2005–2010) was developed at the third TSCC 
Meeting in March 2005 to guide activities in transport cooperation among CAREC countries. 
The road map aims to develop an integrated and efficient transport system in CAREC countries 
and  sets  five  strategic  priorities:  (i)  harmonizing  and  simplifying  cross-border  transport 
procedures  and  documentation,  (ii)  harmonizing  transport  regulations,  (iii)  developing  and 
improving  regional  transport  corridors,  (iv)  restructuring  and  modernizing  railways,  and  
(v) improving sector funding and management. TSCC has become an important mechanism for 
planning, coordinating, and monitoring transport cooperation activities among CAREC countries. 
Because regional cooperation initiatives are resource-intensive and human resource capacity in 
CAREC countries is limited, support to TSCC is crucial to maintain the momentum of regional

5.  The CAREC road map identifies the development and improvement of regional transport 
corridors  as  one  of  the  strategic  priorities.  An  integrated  multimodal  regional  transport 
infrastructure network will strengthen economic links within CAREC countries, give the countries 
better access to outside markets, reduce transport costs, improve transport services and safety, 
and  expedite  cross-border  and  transit  traffic  in  the  region.  This  will  promote  rapid  and 
sustainable development in the nonoil sectors, which will significantly contribute to poverty 
reduction in the region. As part of implementing the road map, the TA will undertake (or update) 
prefeasibility studies on developing and improving three regional transport corridors: Bishkek–
Torugart–Kashi  road,  Oybek–Pungan  road,  and  Angren–Gulistan  road.  The  corridors  were 
selected in close consultation with the governments of CAREC countries. A brief description of 
the transport corridors is given in paragraphs 6–8. 
 
6.  Bishkek–Torugart–Kashi Road. With a length of 604 kilometer (km) (499 km in the 
Kyrgyz Republic and 105 km in the PRC), this road is a potentially important regional transport 
corridor  linking  the  Kyrgyz  Republic  to  the  PRC.  It  starts  in  Bishkek,  bypasses  Balykchy, 
crosses the Kyrgyz–PRC border at Torugart, and continues up to about 105 km to connect with 
a paved road to Kashi. The first 438 km of the road surface from Bishkek is paved and the 
remainder has a gravel surface. Improving this road, accompanied by simplified cross-border 
procedures, will enhance regional transport links, promote trade between Central Asia and the 
Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region of the PRC, and provide an alternative access to South 
Asia from Almaty and Bishkek. A feasibility study on the Bishkek–Torugart section funded by the 
Islamic Development Bank was completed in 1997, and a prefeasibility study on the Balykchy–
Torugart–Kashi section was completed in 1998 under the European Union-funded Transport 
Corridor Europe–the Caucasus–Asia (TRACECA) program. These studies, however, need to be 
updated. 
 
7.  Oybek–Pungan  Road.  The  road,  about  220  km  long,  links  northern  Tajikistan  to 
Uzbekistan. It provides a short route between the Fergana valley and central Uzbekistan, and 
thus serves as an important section of the east–west transport corridor in Central Asia. However, 
the road is in poor condition due to of lack of funding for regular maintenance. Improving this 
road, together with a sound cross-border agreement between Tajikistan and Uzbekistan, will 
facilitate traffic and improve transport efficiency in the region. 
 
8.  Angren–Gulistan Road. This road will form part of the east–west transport corridor in 
Uzbekistan  to  link  the  country  more  closely  with  the  Kyrgyz  Republic  on  the  east  and 
Kazakhstan on the west. Once constructed, the 150 km new road will enable traffic between 
Samarkand and Osh to bypass Tashkent, thus reducing transport costs and travel time as well 
as alleviating traffic congestion in Tashkent. In the long run, the road can serve as a transit 
route between the PRC/Afghanistan and south Europe through western Kazakhstan, Caspian 
Sea,  and  Azerbaijan.  Developing  this  road  will  strengthen  transport  links  among  CAREC 
countries and improve their access to neighboring markets. 
 
9.  Promoting regional cooperation and integration is one of the strategic themes under 
ADB’s Long-Term Strategic Framework (2001–2015).4 Since 1997 ADB has been promoting the 
                                                 
4  ADB. 2001. Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank (2001–2015). Manila.

3
CAREC Program, together with five other multilateral institutions.5 ADB’s Regional Cooperation 
Strategy and Program (RCSP) for CAREC Member Countries6 aims to increase trade and 
integration with large markets, reduce transport costs and facilitate transit, improve supplies of 
energy, and tackle negative externalities. Given the landlocked location of Central Asia, the 
latest RCSP update for CAREC countries reconfirms transport as a priority sector for ADB 
assistance.  ADB  is  the  lead  agency  in  coordinating  transport  cooperation  activities  under 
CAREC and serves as the TSCC secretariat. ADB provided loans for rehabilitating a number of 
regional transport corridors,7 and TAs to prepare investment projects, assess the prefeasibility 
of  developing  the  PRC–Kyrgyz  Republic–Uzbekistan  transport  corridor  and  the  western 
Mongolia regional road corridor, as well as undertake studies to harmonize transport regulations 
and  simplify  cross-border  road/rail  transport  procedures  in  CAREC  countries.  Given  that 
members of CAREC and Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) are largely identical, ADB 
provided a TA in 2004 to help the SCO countries (i.e., PRC, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyz Republic, 
Russian  Federation,  Tajikistan,  and  Uzbekistan)  formulate  an  agreement  on  facilitation  of 
international road transport, together with support from the United Nations Economic and Social 
Commission  for  Asia  and  the  Pacific.8 The  present  TA  is  consistent  with  ADB’s  regional 
cooperation strategy for CAREC countries, and reflects ADB’s continued support for transport 
cooperation under CAREC. 
 
10.  The TA was designed with due consideration of three main lessons learned from the 
CAREC program and the Greater Mekong subregional cooperation program. First, strong and 
sustained commitment of CAREC countries to regional cooperation is key to the TA’s success. 
The governments of CAREC countries reconfirmed their commitment to regional cooperation 
and agreed at the fourth Ministerial Conference in Bishkek, Kyrgyz Republic on 5–6 November 
2005 that transport should continue to be one of the priority sectors. The participants in the 
fourth TSCC Meeting supported the TA proposal. The TA is highly relevant and responsive to 
the needs of CAREC countries. Second, regional cooperation is a long and complex process, so 
consistent external assistance is needed to address constraints and achieve tangible results 
under CAREC. The TA is ADB’s first direct support for transport cooperation among CAREC 
countries. Based on experience gained from the TA, ADB will provide continued assistance for 
regional transport cooperation under CAREC. Third, capacity building for regional cooperation is 
required, given the limited institutional and human resource capacities in CAREC countries.  
The TA will strengthen the capacity of TSCC, with the objective of building effective institutional 
mechanisms for sustainable transport cooperation in the region. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The impact of the TA is facilitation of transport cooperation among CAREC countries to 
achieve sustainable and inclusive economic development in the region. The outcome of the TA 
is  (i)  the  functioning  of  TSCC  as  an  effective  mechanism  for  planning,  coordinating,  and

monitoring  transport  cooperation  activities  among  CAREC  countries;  and  (ii)  prefeasibility 
studies of developing and improving three regional transport corridors (i.e., Bishkek–Torugart–
Kashi  road,  Oybek–Pungan  road,  and  Angren–Gulistan  road)  to  strengthen  transport  and 
economic links among CAREC countries. If the prefeasibility studies show positive results, ADB 
will consider providing further assistance to prepare and finance investment projects.9 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The  TA  is  designed,  and  will  be  implemented,  in  line  with  the  CAREC  Regional 
Transport Sector Road Map (2005–2010) and ADB’s RCSP for CAREC countries, as well as in 
coordination with other regional cooperation initiatives including the Central and South Asia 
Transport and Trade Forum.10 International consultants, with support from domestic consultants, 
will be engaged to undertake (or update) prefeasibility studies on developing and improving the 
selected transport corridors. During assessment of the viability of these corridors, the consultant 
will take into account the national transport development strategies in the CAREC countries 
concerned, or coordinate closely with the consultants working on development of such national 
transport  strategies.11 The  consultant  will  also  provide  on-the-job  training  to  concerned 
government  officials  in  CAREC  countries  to  build  their  capacity  for  assessing  transport 
investment projects. The preparation (or updating) of prefeasibility studies will involve fieldwork, 
office research, and consultation with various stakeholders including government officials, civil 
society, local communities, the private sector, and transport users in the corridor-influenced 
CAREC countries, as well as external development partners.  
 
13.  Key activities in preparing prefeasibility studies of the selected transport corridors will 
include (i) undertaking field surveys; (ii) analyzing data and information collected from field 
surveys to assess technical and economic viabilities of the selected corridors; (iii) assessing 
social,  gender,  and  environmental  impacts  of  the  selected  corridors;  (iv)  holding  public 
consultations; and (v) preparing a prefeasibility study report on developing and improving the 
selected  corridors.  For  each  selected  corridor,  the  prefeasibility  study  report  will  comprise 
engineering assessment, economic assessment, environmental assessment, social and poverty 
analysis, and analysis of cross-border issues. An outline of the prefeasibility study report is in 
Appendix 2.  
 
14.  Key activities under the support of TSCC activities will include (i) facilitating dialogue 
among CAREC countries on transport cooperation issues, (ii) undertaking analytical work in 
support of CAREC transport cooperation activities, (iii) supporting the holding of two TSCC 
meetings each year during 2006–2007, and (iv) enhancing dissemination of knowledge and 
information on CAREC transport cooperation activities. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $650,000 equivalent. The TA will be entirely 
financed on a grant basis by the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan.  
The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 3. The governments of CAREC

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  ADB will be the Executing Agency. ADB’s Transport and Communications Division, East 
and Central Asia Department, will be responsible for administering the TA, with support from 
government agencies in the transport sector in CAREC countries. ADB will collaborate closely 
with  the  European  Bank  for  Reconstruction  and  Development,  Islamic  Development  Bank, 
United Nations Development Programme, World Bank, and other relevant external aid agencies 
during TA implementation. The TA will be implemented in coordination with other regional 
cooperation initiatives including the Central and South Asia Transport and Trade Forum. The TA 
is expected to commence in January 2006 and to be completed at the end of December 2007. 
 
17.  The TA will require 50.0 person-months of consultant inputs (13.0 international and 37.0 
domestic). It will include (i) a consulting firm for 26.0 person-months (13.0 international and 13.0 
domestic) to undertake prefeasibility studies on the development and improvement of three 
selected regional transport corridors, and (ii) an individual domestic consultant for 24.0 person-
months to support TSCC activities. The international consultant’s team for the prefeasibility 
studies will comprise a transport economist/team leader, a road engineer, a social development 
specialist, and an environment specialist. The international consultants will be supported by 
domestic consultants with the same expertise. The governments of the CAREC countries to be 
involved in the prefeasibility studies (i.e., PRC, Kyrgyz Republic, Tajikistan, and Uzbekistan) will 
provide offices with appropriate furnishings, counterpart staff, and administrative support to the 
consultants. The individual domestic consultant to support TSCC activities will have experience 
and expertise in regional transport cooperation. All consultants will be engaged by ADB in 
accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements acceptable to 
ADB for selecting and engaging domestic consultants. The consulting firm will be recruited 
according  to  ADB’s  quality-  and  cost-based  selection  method  using  simplified  technical 
proposals. Outline terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 4. 
 
18.  The prefeasibility study report is expected to be presented at the TSCC meeting in the 
second half of 2006, and will be made publicly available on ADB’s CAREC website upon 
completion. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $650,000 on a grant basis for 
Facilitation  of  Transport  Cooperation  among  Central  Asia  Regional  Economic  Cooperation 
Countries (Phase I), and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will require 50.0 person-months of consultant inputs (13.0 
international and 37.0 domestic). It will include (i) a consulting firm for 26.0 person-months (13.0 
international and 13.0 domestic) to undertake prefeasibility studies on the development and 
improvement  of  three  selected  regional  transport  corridors,  and  (ii)  an  individual  domestic 
consultant for 24.0 person-months to support the Transport Sector Coordinating Committee 
(TSCC) activities. All consultants will be engaged by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in 
accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements acceptable to 
ADB for selecting and engaging domestic consultants. The consulting firm will be recruited 
according  to  ADB’s  quality-  and  cost-based  selection  method  using  simplified  technical 
proposals. Outline terms of reference are given for the consultants involved in each TA output. 
A.  Prefeasibility Study on Development and Improvement of Regional Road 
Corridors 
 
2.  The  consultants  will  undertake  (or  update)  prefeasibility  studies  on  developing  and 
improving three regional transport corridors in the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation 
(CAREC)  countries:  (i)  Bishkek–Torugart–Kashi  road,  (ii)  Angren–Gulistan  road,  and  
(iii)  Oybek–Pungan  road.  The  international  team  will  comprise  a  transport  economist/team 
leader,  a  road  engineer,  a  social  development  specialist,  and  an  environment  specialist.  
The international consultants will be supported by domestic consultants with the same expertise. 
The consultants will undertake prefeasibility studies in line with the CAREC Regional Transport 
Sector Road Map (2005–2010) and the national transport sector strategies in the concerned 
CAREC countries, or should coordinate closely with the consultants working on developing such 
national transport strategies and other regional projects. The consulting services will include, but 
will not be limited to, the following: 
 
  1.  Transport Economist/Team Leader (international, 4.0 person-months) 
 
3.  The expert will undertake the following tasks:   
 
(i)  Serve as Team Leader, work closely with relevant government agencies in the 
concerned CAREC countries, coordinate with other TA consultants, and prepare 
a prefeasibility study report in format and substance satisfactory to ADB and with 
inputs from other consultants. Possibly present the findings of the prefeasibility 
study at the CAREC TSCC meeting in the second half of 2006. 
 
(ii)  Hold consultation with various stakeholders including government officials, civil 
society, nongovernment organizations, the private sector, transport users, and 
external  development  partners  on  developing  and  improving  the  selected 
transport corridors. Take into account the views and suggestions of stakeholders 
during the preparation of the prefeasibility study report. 
 
(iii)  Conduct traffic counts including origin-destination surveys to establish the pattern 
and volume of vehicles, passengers, and freight movements on the selected 
transport corridors. Assess the possibility of passenger and freight traffic diverted 
from  other  routes  and generated  from  economic  growth  along  the corridors. 
Make traffic forecasts by type of domestic, cross-border, and international transit 
traffic on the corridors, taking into account economic and population growth in the 
areas along the corridors.

Appendix 4  11 
(iv)  Assess the economic viability of the selected transport corridors, according to 
ADB’s Guidelines for Economic Analysis of Projects, by comparing with- and 
without-project cases. Calculate the economic internal rate of return and net 
present value for each corridor. Taking into account the economic evaluation, 
least-cost analysis, social benefits, and environmental impact, make appropriate 
recommendations. Undertake sensitivity and risk analyses on the recommended 
ways  of  developing  and  improving  the  corridors.  Prepare  an  economic 
assessment to be included in the prefeasibility study report. 
 
(v)  Assess the status of border crossings along the selected transport corridors, 
identify cross-border constraints on the movement of freight and passengers, and 
propose recommendations to address them. Prepare an analysis of cross-border 
issues, to be included in the prefeasibility study report. 
 
  2.  Road Engineer (international, 3.0 person-months) 
 
4.  The expert will undertake the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Review the proposals, feasibility studies, and preliminary designs on improving 
the Bishkek–Torugart–Kashi road and the Oybeck-Pungan road, and developing 
the Angren–Gulistan road. 
 
(ii)  Undertake engineering surveys to assess the technical viability of developing and 
improving the three selected transport corridors. 
 
(iii)  Identify suitable local roads requiring improvement along the selected corridors to 
improve the access of local communities. 
 
(iv)  Based  on  above  assessments  and  in  consultation  with  other  consultants, 
propose  the  most  suitable  way  of  developing  and  improving  the  selected 
corridors  to  accommodate  projected  traffic  and  meet  national/international 
standards. 
 
(v)  Prepare preliminary cost estimates and a project implementation schedule for 
developing and improving the selected transport corridors.  
 
(vi)  Prepare an engineering assessment of the development and improvement of the 
selected transport corridors, to be included in the prefeasibility study report. 
 
  3.  Environment Specialist (international, 3.0 person-months) 
 
5.  The expert will undertake the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Conduct  a  preliminary  assessment  of  the  environment  along  the  selected 
transport  corridors  by  reviewing  background  documentation,  inspecting  the 
alignment, and public consultation. If required, assess alternative alignments. 
 
(ii)  Make a preliminary assessment of the anticipated environmental impact of the 
selected transport corridors, in accordance with ADB’s Environment Policy, 2002 
and  its  Environmental  Assessment  Guidelines,  2003.  Include  a  preliminary

12  Appendix 4 
 
environmental assessment of local roads, as identified by the international road 
engineer. Propose the environmental category for the projects. 
 
(iii)  Propose measures to mitigate identified negative environmental impacts of the 
selected transport corridors, during the design, construction, and operation of the 
projects. Prepare cost estimates for major mitigating measures for inclusion in 
the  total  project  costs  and  economic  analysis.  Assist  the  international  road 
engineer in incorporating environmental mitigation in the preliminary design and 
costing. 
 
(iv)  Provide recommendations for further environmental assessment to concur with 
relevant  regulations  in  the  CAREC  member  countries  concerned,  ADB’s 
Environment Policy, 2002 and its Environmental Assessment Guidelines, 2003. 
 
(v)  Conduct public consultation on environmental issues along the alignments, in 
accordance with the public consultation and disclosure requirements of ADB’s 
Environmental Assessment Guidelines, 2003. 
 
(vi)  Based on (i)–(v), prepare a report on the preliminary environmental assessment 
of the development and improvement of the selected transport corridors, to be 
included in the feasibility study report. The report will include, but will not be 
limited to (a) brief description of the projects; (b) brief description of the site-
specific  environment,  including  physical  resources,  ecological  resources, 
economic development, and social and cultural resources; (c) assessment of 
project  alternatives;  (d)  anticipated  environmental  impacts  and  mitigating 
measures; and (e) public consultation undertaken. 
 
  4.  Social Development Specialist (international, 3.0 person-months) 
 
6.  The expert will undertake the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Conduct  a  preliminary  poverty,  gender,  and  social  analysis  of  the  selected 
transport corridors in accordance with ADB’s Handbook on Poverty and Social 
Analysis and the Handbook for Integrating Poverty Impact on Economic Analysis 
of Projects through field investigation, public consultation, and analysis of the 
social and poverty data and information in the area along the corridors. 
 
(ii)  Conduct  consultations  with  local  communities  including  the  poor,  women, 
indigenous persons, minorities, and other vulnerable groups on the social and 
gender impact of developing and improving the selected corridors. 
 
(iii)  Assess the need for involuntary resettlement on improving the selected corridors. 
 
(iv)  Based  on  (i)–(iii),  make  a  preliminary  assessment  of  the  social  and  poverty 
reduction impacts of improving the selected corridors. Estimate the proportion of 
the poor among the project beneficiaries.  
 
(v)  Collect information on and assess potential social risks (e.g., HIV/AIDS1 and 
other sexually transmitted infections, and human and drug trafficking), which may 
                                                 
1  HIV/AIDS = human immunodeficiency virus/acquired immunodeficiency syndrome.

Appendix 4  13 
be associated with the improvement of the selected corridors. Based on the 
assessment, propose mitigating measures.  
 
(vi)  Prepare  a  preliminary  social  and  poverty  analysis  of  the  selected  transport 
corridors, to be included in the prefeasibility study report. 
 
  5.  Transport  Economist  (domestic,  4.0  person-months),  Road  Engineer 
  (domestic, 3.0 person-months), Environment Specialist (domestic, 3.0 person-
  months), and Social Development Specialist (domestic, 3.0 person-months) 
 
7.  The expert will undertake the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Assist the international consultant concerned to collect and analyze data and 
information  on  the  selected  transport  corridors,  review  relevant  published 
documents and reports, and help translate relevant reports as required. 
 
(ii)  Advise  the  international  consultants  concerned  of  the  national  and  transport 
sector  development  strategies  to  ensure  that  the  prefeasibility  study  is 
undertaken in line with such document. 
 
(iii)  Assist  the  international  consultants  in  consulting  with  various  stakeholders 
including government officials, civil society, local communities, the private sector, 
transport users, and external development partners.  
 
(iv)  Participate in field surveys and investigations with the international consultants to 
assist in assessing the alignments; conducting traffic counts; making preliminary 
assessments of the economic and technical viabilities and environmental, social, 
and poverty reduction impacts of improving the selected transport corridors; and 
analyzing cross-border issues.  
 
(v)  Provide the international consultants concerned with requested inputs for the 
prefeasibility study report. 
 
(vi)  Facilitate liaison between international consultants and the governments and 
other stakeholders in the concerned CAREC member countries. 
 
(vii)  Perform other tasks that may be requested by international consultants. 
 
8.  The  international  road  engineer,  environment  specialist,  and  social  development 
specialist are required to submit their inputs to the Team Leader in a format acceptable to ADB 
within 12 weeks after the service starts. The inputs include (i) engineering assessment from the 
road engineer, (ii) environmental assessment from the environment specialist, and (iii) social 
and  poverty  analysis  from  the  social  development  specialist.  The  international  transport 
economist is required to prepare economic assessment and analysis of cross-border issues 
within 12 weeks after the service starts. 
 
9.  The team leader will consolidate inputs from the other consultants and submit to ADB 
the  draft  prefeasibility  study  report  within  14  weeks  after  the  service  starts  and  the  final 
prefeasibility study report within 2 weeks after receipt of comments on the draft prefeasibility 
study report. The draft and the final prefeasibility study reports will be submitted to ADB in 
accordance with the format in Appendix 2 and in seven copies (3 in English and 4 in Russian).

14  Appendix 4 
 
The team leader will also submit to ADB an electronic copy of the draft and final prefeasibility 
study reports (in Word or Excel format, and in compact disc) and an executive summary (in 
Word and PowerPoint) in English and in Russian at the end of service. 
 
B.  Support for Activities of the CAREC Transport Sector Coordinating Committee  
 
10.  A domestic consultant with experience and expertise in regional transport cooperation 
will be engaged for 24 person-months to assist in TSCC activities including preparing for two 
TSCC meetings each year during 2006 and 2007. The consultant will be based in the TSCC 
secretariat at ADB headquarters. The consulting services will include, but will not be limited to, 
the following: 
 
(i)  Coordinate with CAREC countries, CAREC secretariat, and ADB focal points in 
the Transport and Communication Division, East and Central Asia Department, in 
collecting and analyzing information and data related to transport cooperation 
activities under CAREC, and other related initiatives. 
 
(ii)  Assist in preparing background materials, maps, briefing papers, presentations, 
and reports to be used at the TSCC meetings. 
 
(iii)  Make logistical arrangements for TSCC meetings, including arranging venues, 
preparing  travel  documents  for  participants  from  CAREC  countries,  and 
coordinating translation of documents. 
 
(iv)  Assist in monitoring activities, outputs, and performance against the CAREC 
Regional Transport Sector Road Map (2005–2010). 
 
(v)  Assist in updating transport sector activities on the CAREC website. 
 
(vi)  Perform other tasks that may be requested by the TSCC secretariat.
